newsitem.title: USA: Top US Democratic Senator hopeful on budget pact.
newsitem.headline: Top US Democratic Senator hopeful on budget pact.

text.p: Senate Democratic Leader Tom Daschle of South Dakota said Tuesday he was hopeful the White House and the Republican-controlled Congress would be able to work out an agreement this year to balance the budget.

"I think we have the possibility of resolving our budget problems successfully," Daschle told reporters shortly before President Clinton was due at the Capitol to meet with leaders of both parties on the budget and other issues.
Daschle said he believed there had been good faith efforts by both parties to avoid the confrontations that had shut down the government briefly last year.
Daschle said he thought the most difficult issues to resolve would be proposed tax cuts and Medicare financing.
"They (Republicans) are offering again extravagant tax cuts. Ours are much more targeted," he said.
Daschle said the Senate vote on a balanced budget constitutional amendment remained too close to call. The amendment needs 67 votes in the 100-member Senate for the required two-thirds majority.
Daschle said he would not agree to a time for a final vote until all Democrats had a chance to offer their amendments. "We're not going to be pushed into an artificial deadline."
